34926287.review:
Great colorful old-school shoot'em up (pre-bullet hell) which perfectly captures the spirit of it's inspiration - 70's mech anime. You have five different characteers (with their own mech) that can combine into variations, each with their own sub-weapon, bomb and charge attack, and with a unique way of handling weapon upgrades. For a game of this type it's also unusually story-rich, with visual novel-style dialogue scenes between the stages detailing the relationships between the characters.

With a catchy and heroic soundtrack setting the theme, it's definitely recommended for all fans of old-school shoot 'em ups! It's also relatively accessible, with several difficulty settings.

29040011.review:
Supercharged Robot VULKAISER!


This game is a tremendous amount of fun. It's a fairly simple, straightforward shmup. The major twist gameplay-wise is the "VulFighter" system that changes your attack pattern in one of four ways - if you elect to even combine with any of the VulFighters at all, of course. Each one gives you a new bullet pattern and one-use "Omega Weapon" to fire back at wave upon wave of enemies with, from the wide-firing Needle Kaiser to the highly-damaging but close-range Drill Kaiser, and they each feel just different enough to be able to have a favorite - and to feel terrible if you take enough damage for your VulFighters to be knocked out of commission for the rest of your run.

The story is a great homage to classic Super Robot shows like Mazinger Z and is pretty fun, but as much as I like it, it really isn't anything to write home about. But then again, who plays Shmups for their story?

The game is a solid 9/10 if you're a fan of giant robots, shoot-em-ups, or both.

28688840.review:
Uooooooh! My blood just begins BOILING when I PLAY this GAME! Evil, beware, for the SUPERCHARGED ROBOT VULKAISER shall take you down!

This TOTALLY ACCURATE retelling of the events of 1977 entails the BATTLE between Vulkaiser, a SUPER ROBOT developed by Professor Amamori with VULKANIUM and piloted by the HEROICALLY quiet Akatsuki Takuya, and the Gogoh Army's EARTH INVASION forces, led by General Roz. 

FLYING in the sky, a SYMBOL of JUSTICE, Vulkaiser is near-invincible! Attacks can't even TOUCH its arms and legs, but do mind the reactor in its CHEST. (It doesn't shoot beams.) Armor can only do SO MUCH to PROTECT it, until it EXPLODES! Pressing Z will allow Vulkaiser to FIRE its Shoulder Vulcans (which are, obviously, not located on its head), and it can be fired in a CONTINUOUS STREAM if it's held down. Should one fire LONG ENOUGH, Vulkaiser will fire its MISSILE FISTS when one stops firing, even for a split second. Timed correctly, one can CONTINUOUSLY LAY DOWN a stream of DESTRUCTIVE JUSTICE upon the Gogoh Army!

However, Akatsuki is NOT ALONE in his journey! With the HELP of his four PARTNERS, he can COMBINE with a VulFighter to UPGRADE Vulkaiser's capabilities, enhancing its Shoulder Vulcans and Missile Fists into something EVEN BETTER. In addition, he'll gain ACCESS to an OMEGA WEAPON, a potent ONE-USE ability that can LAY WASTE to enemies. This may be UNLEASHED with X. Be strategic in using it, however! You only get one.
 - Yukimasa Murata provides the VulFighter for ROCKET KAISER, a veritable KING of laying down BARRAGE after BARRAGE of powerful BUSTER MISSILES, then FINISHING OFF with a VulCannon. However, the missiles have a SHORT DELAY before BLASTING OFF, so make sure that they are TACTICALLY PLACED down (or is it up?), so that you can SHOUT, "I have you now!" at your opponents, without looking like an ABSOLUTE FOOL. Its Omega Weapon is the IRON TYPHOON, a STREAM of ENDLESS DESTRUCTION in front of Rocket Kaiser.
 - Usui Kimiko allows Akatsuki to utilize the NEEDLE KAISER, whose NEEDLE SHOT and NEEDLE STORM have INCREDIBLE RANGE, and its Omega Weapon, CORONA FIELD, blasts anything surrounding Vulkaiser. However, its attacks have PITIFUL FIREPOWER, so don't even think about taking this to a cannonfight.
 - Yamashito Kaiko pilots the Thunder Fighter, which can COMBINE with Vulkaiser to FORM the THUNDER KAISER. Its THUNDER LASER provides both POWER, SPEED, and RANGE, and the THUNDER BLASTER shaves through any EVIL in its way. HOWEVER, its Omega Weapon, THUNDER FLASH, is fantastically WEAK, even if it hits the entire area. This one in particular is a FAVORITE of mine.
 - Jujo Suzuna grants Akatsuki access to the DRILL KAISER, and with it, the powerful DRILL TORNADO, a weapon capable of surpassing the HEAVENS. However, aside from DRILL MISSILE, Drill Kaiser has LITTLE to NO RANGE, as its Omega Weapon, DRILL BLAZER, is simply an EXTENSION of its normal ATTACK. Truly, a HIGH-SKILL, HIGH-REWARD combination!

28112979.review:
As a fan of Gatchaman!, Voltron, Tekkaman Blade, and Robotech I had an absolute blast with this game. As a matter of fact, when I watched the trailer for it, I had to double check online to make sure this wasn't an adaptation of a more obscure series. The creators get mad points for that.

So, at its core, Vulkaiser is a horizontal bullet hell shooter. Coolio. In keeping with its theme of retro anime mecha, your core mech is equipped with a standard, but weak, vulcan cannon. A charge meter at the bottom of the screen constantly fills up as you shoot: activating it fires off a more powerful shot. In addition to your core mech there are four other parts to the Vulkaiser that you can combine with during each stage, each with its own unique weapon. A cluster of missiles, a close-range drill, a weak but screen-filling spread shot, and a wide electric attack. The idea of mixing and matching your mech on the fly reminds me of an older NES shooter, Mag Max, although Vulkaiser is more fleshed out.

With all of its various mech parts and special weapon gauges, is Vulkaiser worth playing? Yes. I was able to beat the game in my first attempt without dying. I came close by the end, and two of my partners had to bail a la Starfox, but it was doable. But what's cool are the multiple levels of diffculty. Too easy your first playthrough? Crank it up a level. I can see myself coming back to this in the future to try out the harder diffuculties.

Is Vulkaiser the best shooter I've ever played? No. But it's certainly fun and what it lacks in depth in makes up for in style. Totally worth a buy if you're a fan of the genre or of classic mecha anime. Rick Hunter would be proud.

26429072.review:
[h1]◁ 초혈열로봇 볼카이져 Supercharged Robot VULKAISER ▷
고전 로봇물과 비슷한 복고풍의 비행슈팅게임[/h1]

역시 일본 고전 애니의 오마주(패러디)이다.
제목에서도 알수 있다. 오래전에 나온 일본슈퍼로봇의 제목에는 앞에 수식어가 붙고 다음에 로봇이름을 쓰는 방식인데, 
가령, 초전자로봇 콤바트라V, 초전자머신 볼테스V, 절대무적 라이징오, 무적강인 다이탄3, 용자경찰 제이데커, 용자왕 가오가이거 등.... 모두 이런식이다.
이 게임도 그런 제목을 형식을 그대로 취했다.
고전 게임에서 머리가 차가운 주인공보다는 머리와 피가 뜨거운(?) 혈열적인 주인공이 인기였는데, 그레이트 마징가의 테츠야보다는 마징가Z의 카부토 고우지같은 주인공들...
예외가 없는건 아니지만...(그랜다이져의 주인공 듀크 프리드는 혈열적이지 않으면서도 인기가 많았다. 귀공자타입으로...)
이 게임의 제목부터가 초혈열이다. ^^;

이런 로봇이 등장하는 게임을 참 좋아했지만 이런 로봇 게임을 접하는건 많지가 않다.
일본 게임 중 슈퍼로봇대전 시리즈가 그나마 추억을 생각하며 할수 있는 게임인데...
이 게임도 추억을 생각하며 만들어진 게임으로 보인다.

70~90년대의 로봇물의 분위기가 물씬 풍기는 로봇이 등장하는 횡스크롤식 슈팅게임.
로봇의 디자인은 건담과 신혼합체 고단나를 합쳐놓은 듯한 느낌이다.
게임은 작년까지 모바일로 서비스되었던 1994 로봇킹 for Kakao와 비슷한 형태의 게임이다.
보조 파츠에 따라 공격의 형태가 조금씩 달라지는데 이러한 방식은 그랜다이져와 상당히 흡사하다.
적대장은 볼테스V의 프린스 하이넬을 연상시키는 캐릭터이다.
여기저기가 가져온 오마주(페러디)적 요소들.
고전 추억의 로봇물 좋아했던 유저들에게는 환호받을만한 게임이다.

가격도 저렴한 편이고 도전과제 및 트레이딩 카드까지 갖추고 있는 게임이고 스팀 클라우드까지 작동하니 저장기능도 좋은 게임이다. 
일본사람들의 애니사랑, 로봇사랑이 돋보이는 게임.
추억을 생각하면서 한번쯤 해보는 것도 좋은 게임이다.




평점 80점.

昭和年代風格的機器人彈幕射擊遊戲《超電気ロボ バルカイザー》……這取名不就是拿『超電磁ロボ』混搭『マジンカイザー』嘛混帳wwwwwwwwwwwww。

嗯哼，《超電気ロボ バルカイザー》起初是同人團體ASTRO PORT製作的彈幕射擊遊戲，最初的發售日是2007年9月，算算也是快十年的遊戲了，不愧是Nyu Media，深知如何炒冷飯(?)。這冷飯有點香就是了(???)。

凱薩機器人(有了)、合體(有了)、飛拳(有了)、擁有神秘科技力的博士(有了)、怪人軍團(有了)、宇宙怪獸入侵(也有了)。

博士乾脆去演地球最終之日算了。(ryyyyyyyyyyyyyy

嗯？你問我難度？當然是 爆★幹★難！六大關卡、四種難度，其難度間距之大都快吐血了。簡單→如字面上所述，普通→正常彈幕發揮中，稍難→WTF……，極難→我累了，這片畫面一定是幻覺。

開啟遊戲之後記得調整一下遊戲視窗，預設有點小。
然後準備被怪人軍團消滅(誤)。

遊戲提醒：
1、支援機的大絕只能使用一次，必須切換支援機才能補充。
2、支援機有四種。飛彈、散彈、雷射與鑽頭。鑽頭武器『集氣』雖然擁有彈切的效果，但是前三個關卡不適合使用。

25338367.review:
So, overall this game is pretty great.

The gameplay is solid, the controls are good (MUCH better with a gamepad) and the 70s mecha anime aesthetics are spot on and really capture what they're going for.

And then there's the stuff that's not so great.

Resolution: The resolution in this game is set and can not be changed. I get they did this to make it seem more "authentic" along the lines of the non-widescreen anime of the 20th century, but having it stuck at a constant 400x600 makes it look ugly, gives less space to see projectiles, and causes the steam overlay to act weird, making achievements and notifications take up nearly a quarter of the screen. Also there is no pause button.

Content: While I did enjoy this game I felt like it was kinda lacking in content. For five dollars you get 5 levels and varying difficulty modes. This can get stale quickly and unless you enjoy repeating the same levels over and over, trying to get new high scores or complete different difficulties you may find yourself bored very quickly.

However, if you can look past these small flaws this game is very enjoyable and is a great time waster. Would recommend to mecha fans and anyone with some extra funds in their steam wallets.

25330663.review:
[h1]Ta-ta-ta-ta-ta[/h1]

I don't know what to say. Have you ever played a game which was so good and so bad at once?

[h1]Crush the evil plans[/h1]

I would [b]love[/b] to just select "Recommended" and write "Buy this game, it's awesome" then click "Submit", because it is. But why, oh why have the developers done the things to their game they did?

[h1]Gogoh Invaders from Spaaaaace[/h1]

For starters, the game is a solid shoot 'em up. As you progress, you can change your robot's features by selecting the modules to use when the game offers to. You have a special charge attack, a Big Red Button, more than awesome music, more than awesome animations in the style of a late 70s anime. You have achievements, leaderboards, trading cards, ...

So what's wrong with this game?

Everything which is not gameplay-related:

[list]
[*]You cannot change resolution. You have 640x480 or something similarly small resolution to deal with like it or not. This results all of your other open applications resizing themselves when you quit.
[*]Also, with such a low resolution you cannot use your Steam overlay while in-game.
[*]You cannot switch between windowed mode and full screen. The game asks you if you want to go to full screen when you start, and that's it. Once you make your choice, you will stick to it until you quit.
[*]No options menu. At all. So no volume sliders, no control rebindings, nothing.
[*]You cannot pause. The devs mentioned somewhere that it's intentional as they want to simulate the arcade feeling where you cannot pause. Yeah, but in the arcade you dropped your quarter and played while it lasted without leaving. However, while you play your computer your girlfriend will occasionally call you (if you have one), the kids will call you (if you have those), and the postman will ring the bell so you need to leave your computer in the middle of your game.
[*]Related to the previous issue: when you press Esc, the game just goes back to the menu. Without asking.
[/list]

Why do I feel angry about all of these? Because this is one of the best shooters I've ever played. Love the style, love the graphics, the music, the controls. Yet they managed to release this masterpiece with all these issues which is unforgivable.

Buy this game for the fun, or avoid it because of the technical execution... Your choice. For myself, I think I'll keep having fun with it. But also keep asking the question hopelessly to myself: "Why, oh why have the devs done this to their wonderful game?".

An extremely short (6 stage) but fun filled romp.

There's little to no story. I guess you can keep using the same one of four units over and over for each stage JUST to see what they say, but other than that the story is super simple and 70's esque. Its a fun nostalgia fest.

As for the gameplay, it was challenging. If you are new to shmups, easy will feel like "hard mode".

It involves using 4 unique power ups: drill, thunder, rocket, and needle. Each one with their own strengths, weaknesses, uber moves, and "mini uber", which is activated by letting go of the fire button when the "charge" is filled up. The way the shooting has a charge meter adds a nice rhythm to the shooting, with each unique charge filling up once every 3 seconds or so. Its a nice unique way to add a small gameplay dimension to the shooting instead of the usual "hold down fire and aim the ship".

Is this game a masterpiece? Heavens no. Is this game worth the price, ESPECIALLY on sale? Definately.

22238960.review:
An endearing homage to old timey giant robot shows and fan subs, packed in an arcade style bullet hell. Challenging even on the easiest difficulty setting, and sometimes punishingly so, given how you only get partial repairs between stages and if a module gets destroyed, it's gone for good. 
Fun if you like bullet hell style games and giant robots with the 70s and 80s mix of cheesy, over the top and ludicrous fun, but it suffers from a lack of options. You can't quite pause the game, change resolution (watch out for the huge Steam popups in the corner) or reconfigure the controls, but if you can get past those annoyances, you're in for a treat. 
Just don't expect to clear the whole thing on the first attempt. You have only one life, your robot and modules are quite flimsy, and evasion is the name of the game. Expect the level of ludicrous bullet hell to climb exponentially on the higher difficulties. Fun, but indubitably with its frustrating moments.

20243684.review:
A sidescrolling SHMUP in the vein of 1970's SUPER ROBOT mecha anime. WITH YELLOW SUBTITLES!

It's pretty gawd-dammed perfect as far as what it sets out to do. You shoot all of the the things while bombastic music plays in the background facing a recurring miniboss and so many enemies that are obvious references to the tatsunoko era of anime. It's very self-aware and pretty glorious. 

Best of all, there's actually some interesting design choices for the genre, so you'll actually find a different gameplay experience here. Namely in the health system. Rather than being a 1HP hero, you have a fairly meaty health bar, but it carries over from stage to stage and only gets some repairs between stages. Moreover, your co-pilot partners who act as your powerups also have their own, much smaller, health bars and just like in Star Fox they can get KO'd for good if you're too careless through the short 30 minute campaign. 

Plus, rather than a whole bunch of bombs in a stage like most shoot 'em ups, you only get one OMEGA BOMB per stage to use when the going gets tough, so strategic deployment of both your team mates and when you pull out your super move is actually fairly critical. 

And it's all executed flawlessly. Literally the only complaint I have is that the video used to sell the game with the sung VULKAISER themesong isn't actually in the game. If it was it'd be 110% perfect!

As it is, I'll just settle for 100% perfect. 

Go, Go, VULKAISER! Destroy them with your super electricity!

18457156.review:
A great little arcade shooter well worth the asking price. Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser is a short bullet hell shooter that parodies the 70s giant robot anime genre. Vulkaiser only has five levels but it's an addictive game with great presentation and replay value. You take control of the titular Vulkaiser and it's pilot Takuya Akatsuki dodging bullets and blasting waves of enemies as you defend earth from androgynous alien invader General Roz. Vulkaiser can combine with four other vehicles developed by Professor Amamori and piloted by Takuya's allies, each one offering Vulkaiser new attacks, knowing when to choose which unit becomes part of Vulkaiser's strategy as you deal with the varying threats the alien menace poses.

This is a great indy title from Japanese developer Astro Port and at it's budget price can't afford to be missed, arcade gamers and bullet hell fans alike will love it. definitely pick it up.

18447337.review:
I didn't really enjoy Satazius that much yet i really enjoyed Gigantic Army so when Supercharged Robot VULKAISER hit steam i had some interest in it but i never got around buying/playing it but now that i finally decided to give it a chance i'm more than impressed.

The presentation is fantastic, It's just like a semi-cheesy japanese Sentai, It even has those big yellow subtitles which i found amazing, the music is great and the characters and art are very appealing.

The gameplay is really fun, You pilot the Vulkaiser robot which by itself it has a regular forward shot that when charged releases a Rocket Punch attack, it's really cool that it charges as you shoot, so you don't actually have to stop shooting at any point, You just let go of the button when the gauge is full to use your "Special" attack.

That's pretty cool and all but the best part is that you get 4 secondary pilots with smaller ships that pop up at certain parts of the stages so you can "Combine" with them, This adds a secondary shot on top of your regular shot as well as changing your special attack completely and giving you a unique smart bomb depending on which pilot/ship you combine with, Smart bombs refill whenever you combine with a new pilot so it's a great resource to your arsenal which you aren't punished at all for using.

You have a long lifebar which takes around 13~ (Give or take) hits which gets refilled a little between stages which makes the game very lenient when it comes to difficulty, also, each pilot has their own lifebar so switching them out after you take damage is something to consider, If their ship blows up during a run it can't be repaired anymore and you have to start over to get them back, this is a great way to make you switch out ships if you are constantly taking damage, but of course, if you don't take damage you don't actually have to ever switch out if unless you want to due to strategical advantage, given that each combination has their unique shot types and special attacks.

After getting the 1CC in Normal difficulty (There's 4 difficulties total) I can safely say Supercharged Robot VULKAISER is a great game worth playing, the enemy variation is great, the constant DARIUS homages are fantastic and c'mon this game has giant Robots shooting at stuff and there's so much stuff going on in every stage, how are you gonna say this game is not the jam? :)

18369388.review:
Mankind is well and truly doomed for certain this time! Invaders from another dimension in another galaxy have arrived to take over, control, as well as enslave Earth! You, the most heroic man of all time and space, must pilot the Supercharged Robot VULKAISER in order to save existence itself from the greatest threat that could possibly be imagined in forever! Whether you grew up with Voltron, know your Ultramans from your Jet Jaguars, or just enjoy quality 2D shooters, there's something for you in this game. 

This is a horizontally-scrolling shooter, but it's more of a danmaku than Gradius or R-Type. Even though I've been using the word "danmaku" for over a decade, I only just now looked it up. Apparently it means "barrage", and that definitely applies to VULKAISER. The alien armada doesn't mess around, as they'll throw battalion after battalion at you until your health meter is depleted. Yep, this is a shmup with health, and it can even be restored in-between stages. However, you only get one life and no continues. So yeah, you have just one chance to save the world, better make the most of it.

So how do you handle this situation? With a barrage of your own. The VULKAISER isn't all that effective by itself though. Over the course of each stage you can combine powers with your four best buddies. This results in increased firepower, different weapons, and screen-clearing Omega attacks. The option to swap partners presents itself at various points in the game. Sometimes you'll want a particular weapon for the next area, or the health of your current ally is running low. Yep, everyone has health meters. If they're wiped out, there's nothing you can do for them. Hopefully you can honor their sacrifice by saving the world. This lends a touch of resource management to an otherwise simplistic game.

Each of the six stages offers a good mix of smaller "popcorn" enemies, larger battleships, and a handful of mid-sized cronies. As with any other barrage shooter, you have a hitbox that's much smaller than your actual robot. It's rather odd to get used to, even for someone genre-savvy like myself. You'll adjust to it over-time, and the first two difficulties aren't too bad when it comes to throwing bullets around. The sixth and final stage does present a rather sizable jump in difficulty. In my last play-through on the normal setting, I barely eked out a win, even though I went into it with full health. For the most part though, you're going to be crushing loads of enemies with lots of firepower. It's very satisfying. The 70s aesthetics and music have their appeal as well, though admittedly it's lost on me since I never watched Giant Robot shows (Aside from Robotech but that's more Space Opera). 

With play-throughs lasting just under 20 minutes, this game is on the short side. Much of the replay value is going to come from improving upon high-scores and attempting the harder difficulties. VULKAISER isn't a content-rich game, but neither are most 2D shooters. All that really matters is if a shmup delivers on the fundamentals, and I think this one does. The stages are fairly designed, the bosses are well-done, the controls are solid, and everything functions as it should. Also, I believe the shorter than average length works to this game's benefit. The action is tightly-paced and doesn't suffer from any wasted time.

I highly recommend giving Supercharged Robot VULKAISER a look.

It's a great bullet-hell shooter that's entirely in the style of a classic 70's mecha anime like Mazinger Z, UFO Robot Grendizer, & Getter Robo (Which makes it infinitely better than most games of this genre if you ask me, aside from this and Capsule Force there needs to be more games of this kind of motif on Steam). My only complaint  which is a minor one considering the intended nature of the game is that it's a bit too unforgiving since you only have one life and no continues, not to mention that once your Vulkaiser modules are destroyed they are gone for good. I had no issue clearing the game on easy for the first time without losing a single module but that isn't the case on normal where I got up to the second to-last boss in virtually the same manner.

Do mind that this is largely unaltered Steam Release of an old Japanese indie/doujin game so there isn't much in the way of an options menu, high resolutions, or additional modes/features other than training & replay.

Cette ambiance couplé à une excellente B.O. et à un gameplay agréable, permet à ce jeu de posséder une excellente rejouabilité. C'est en effet avec plaisir qu'on se prend à refaire le jeu encore et encore afin de progresser dans les difficultés supérieures. Elles sont au nombre de 4 : facile (faisable par la majorité des joueurs), normal (un défi abordable pour tout amateur de shoot'em up du dimanche), hard (La ça commence à vraiment se corser) et super hard (Difficulté réservée à l'élite). 

Le gameplay est celui d'un shoot classique en défilement horizontale. La particularité de celui ci se situe au niveau du changement d'armes. En effet, 2 fois par niveau, on pourra "fusionner"  avec l'un des 4 modules et ainsi changer son approche en fonction de la partie du niveau.

Un achat que je conseille fortement pour tout les amateurs de shmup ou de gameplay à l'ancienne.

17748550.review:
The retro styled Supercharged Robot VULKAISER with it's 2d side scrolling shootem up wins hands down.

The story is very minimal, but can have minor changes based on which powerups you used, but none of this affects the primary story line. The other characters have minimal parts, but the real charm about SRV, is how classic and simple it is.

Fly through levels and defeat both mini-bosses and regular bosses with your Vulkaiser. Bits of mini dialogue have it stand out from your typical side scrolling shooter, and will likely remind you of super giant robot sized mecha anime of the past.

With variable difficulty from easy to super hard, this game can go from a casual shooter that still challenges to a wicked hard bullet hell that will keep you trying again and again.

With a price tag of about $5, the game is actually well worth it. It has replayability due to the multiple achievements and the different dialogues between stages. 

The one negative is that it is a little short, but the developers have recently stepped up and addressed community issues, fixing their concerns.

Overall, I'd give Supercharged Robot VULKAISER an 8 out of 10.

If any of you have ever played Wonderful 101, or Power Rangers on the SNES, or Viewtiful Joe, or watched Combattler V or Gunbuster, you'll definitely be familiar with that ol hokey sentai theme. I find it charming, and Astro Port brings it here with all of its cheesiness intact, along with a good sidescrolling shoot em up, that has a 4-way variety of powerups and combinations for your giant robot that alters gameplay with each one. For 6 dollars you can't go wrong. And don't expect a pushover game either. On the subject of lives and difficulty, this game runs on the ARMED SEVEN system, wherein you get one life with limited health. You can take a beating, and you get health regenerated after every round, but one life is all you get. I wish the game was longer, but only because of how much joy I had in the short time I had with it. You'll complete it within an hour sadly, but it has good replay value with harder difficulties and additional character dialog, though I still wish it was a bit longer, since wonderful games like W101 do provide more length for their value.  Also, since the game is older than the steam release date would let on, the devs might not have all the new features worked out yet. Some achievements dont work, for example. a Minor issue. 

Regarding my thoughts on the game as a whole, in the words of Wonder Red, Viewtiful Joe and Wooldor Sockbat,

"UNITE THUMBS UP"
"HENSHIN A GO-GO"
"funny third thing"

Desde el primer momento, el juego rinde homenaje a los animes de mechas de los 70 como Mazinger Z, Dai Apollon o Gatchaman. El apartado gráfico es muy sencillo, bebiendo directamente de la animación japonesa y los juegos de SNES para presentarnos una nave-robot protagonista que vuela por los cielos a través de unos niveles de escenarios simples y vacíos llenos de enemigos suficientemente variados y con unos diseños muy coloridos y atractivos. La jugabilidad toma como base el típico shooter horizontal con power-ups pero con un giro ingenioso al poder fusionarnos con diferentes naves amigas que se acoplarán a nuestro robot cambiando sus ataques. En total recorremos seis fases con una duración total de juego de unos 40 minutos, bien ajustado para que no se haga ni demasiado corto ni demasiado largo.

Supercharged Robot VULKAISER es un shooter divertido y encantador, con un apartado audiovisual que homenajea con cariño los animes de mechas de los 70, dando unos giros ingeniosos a las mecánicas habituales del género y creando una experiencia equilibrada y muy entretenida.

17495465.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
VulKaiser, a shoot-'em-up 70's mecha anime styled little game.
There are no FMV, voices, ground-breaking graphics, etc...
This a return back to 80s old-school MAME/Arcade era.

[h1]Concept & Story[/h1]
Unless you are a big old-school mecha fan of the days of [b]Mazinger Z, Grendizer, Getter Robo and Jeeg[/b]
you probably won't find anything interesting in this game. As this game is a mock of the above-mentioned animes.

The Story is extremely simple, you are a new little guy that got picked up to pilot Earth's strongest robot (70's cliche basic plot). You fight Aliens that decided to invade Earth (70's mecha plot standard).

The Game is also mock the infamous and terrible "Yellow-Subtitles" that is found when downloading old anime online. It's called HK-Subs or HK-Releases. Hong Kong release these animes with EngRish Subtitles, colored Yellow and it's laughibly terrible. 


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As a 2D shoot-'em-up game, there's nothing much to highlight about the gameplay.
Your robot has support team, where each one has unique plane that combines with you that gives you different weapons and abilites. Vulkaiser can combine into 4 different planes to become "ThunderKaiser, DrillKaiser, NeedleKaiser or RockerKaiser"
each has their own weapons set and super attack.

The game is challenging, where you will see "Bullet-Hell" moments a lot. and no power-ups other than the mentioned support planes. and no HP-Regeneration until Level-Complete (just a small health boost though.

The Game consists of 6 Levels (Probably more with hard and Super Hard modes), each level in a different location (Earth, Space, Monster's body, etc..) and a unique boss.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Game only run at 4:3 screen with 640x840 Resolution
- You can't modify game files. A shame really i wanted to put some other music from my favorite 70's mecha shows.
- Game can be beaten in 15~30 minutes, afterwards nothing much to do except playing again and again to get all the achievements or trying harder modes.


[h1]Similar Games[/h1]
-70'S ROBOT ANIME GEPPY X (PS1): Both games are extremely alike, both mock up the 70's mecha genre. This game however, has FMV Opening, Ending and even "Mid-Episode" Commerical Ad. It's like a TV Show!

-Mazinger Z (MAME): except it's vertical but pretty much similar.

-Gradius (NES): same game, instead of robots, it's a space jetfighter.

I Hope i wrote everything about the game that let you decide weather to get it or not.
But if you want my advise, Unless you are 20~40 years old that remember the good old days of robot shows like Mazingers and Getter Robo, and/or if it's not in "unregrettable-price" sale, don't get this game.

7.5/10

17437747.review:
I'm a fan of all of Astro Port's games on Steam (Satazius, Gigantic Army, Armed Seven), and this one is no exception. In fact, it might be my favorite of the bunch. It nails the 70s anime aesthetic, is self-aware enough to laugh with and not at, and the shooting action is superb. This is how I remember my favorite 16-bit shooters feeling.

Yes, it lacks options. It could use customizable controls (or at the very least, a screen that shows you the controls, period!), screen resolution settings, saving, pausing... none of that is here. For some, that might be a deal-breaker. But it's so much fun that I can look past those flaws. It's pure arcade joy.

If I had my way, General Roz would reach the same level of notoriety as CATS from Zero Wing.  Without spoiling anything, his battle cries in levels 3 and 5 are pure gold.

17427690.review:
1970年代のロボットアニメをほうふつとさせる見た目とストーリーが特徴の横スクロールシューティングゲーム（やや弾幕系で完全ライフ制。）で全6面。

イージーからスーパーハードまでの4段階の難易度調整や今まで進んだステージや内部難易度を自由に選んで遊ぶ「トレーニングモード」や各難易度別の最高得点のプレイを再生する「リプレイモード」があり。
（ステージの選択範囲は難易度別になっている。なお、トレーニングモードではハイスコアやリプレイは記録されない。）

ゲーム内容は方向バッドもしくは右スティックで自機の移動。Aボタンでショット。（オート連射。溜め撃ちあり。）BボタンでΩ（オメガ）ウェポン（いわゆるボム。オプション幾と合体する毎に1回使用可能）と非常にシンプル。
（ボタン表記はXinputパッドでの表記。念の為。）

自機のパワーアップアイテムの類は一切無く、道中に現れる4種類のオプション機と合体することでパワーアップ＋Ωウェポンを1回だけ使用することすることが出来るが、合体したオプション機も自機とは別にライフを持っており、敵の攻撃でオプション機が破壊されるとそのゲーム内では二度と復活しないので注意が必要。
（ちなみに合体するオプション機によって溜め撃ちやΩウェポンも変化する。また、合体していない時に限り、自機のHPが極限に少なくなると溜め撃ち(ロケットパンチ）に弾消し属性が加わる。〉

難易度のほうはノーマルランクでプレイした限りでは自機の当たり判定が見た目よりも小さいことやオプション兵器の性能が結構高いせいもあってか、合体するオプション機を間違えなければ簡単過ぎず、難しすぎずと個人的に良い塩梅なバランスなうえ、画面上を多い尽くす大量の雑魚を溜め撃ちで一掃する爽快感がなかなか良い感じの破壊音とあいまって個人的に良い感じ。
（もちろん個人差あり。）

また、コテコテなキャラクターデザインや、ややチープなシューティングパートのグラフィックス。いかにもって感じのノリノリな音楽。
さらに極めつけは「敵幹部が乗る中ボスを倒すとその幹部が脱出用の小型艇で脱出する」「プレイヤー機の(あまり似ていない）偽者が出てくる」等の演出がいかにも70年代ロボットアニメしていて、個人的に「製作者は70年代ロボットアニメを解かっていらっしゃる」と思った。

ただ、キーコンフィグや画面の解像度が変更出来ない。（一応起動時にフルスクリーンモードにするか聞いてくるが、、）プロモーション映像で流れていたオープニングテーマのボーカル曲がゲーム中で流れないなどのマイナス点もあるが、（個人的にはラスボス戦で流してくれれば結構盛り上がると思うが、、）価格もお手ごろなうえゲーム自体もそんなに悪くない出来なので、横スクロールシューティングゲームが好きな方はぜひ、、
（まぁ、コテコテな内容ゆえ、若干人を選びそうだが、気になる人は1度体験版（Win版のみ）をプレイすると良いだろう。）

Ps,一応完全日本語版も「超電気ロボ バルカイザー」というタイトルでDLsite（324円（Win版のみ））などで同じデベロッパーが開発したゲーム（注）とともに販売しています。念のため、、

注、中には海外のSteamでは配信されているが日本では未配信となっている（いわゆる「おま国」）作品もありました。

追記：最初、ゲームクリア実績など一部の実績が解除されないというバグがあったと書きました、2015年8月末に行われたアップデートで修正されました。

17330452.review:
Supercharged Robot VULKAISER is a game where you take on the role of a supercharged robot which is allegedly named Vulkaiser. Now that we've gotten the obvious out of the way...

Basically, you're in a mech suit, you fly around a screen, and you shoot lots of lasers, bullets, lightening, and a couple other things at a bunch of other mech suits and spaceships. It's a callback to games like Gradius, where the enemies come in specific waves, ending in a boss battle. Repeat the formula two or three times, and you have yourself an entire level. Repeat that formula a couple dozen times, and you have the game I'm currently reviewing.

This is not to suggest the game falls short of entertaining. I got it in a Humble Bundle with a dollar donation, so I can't really complain, but it's not often I find something I'll actually play again in the veritable bin of indie games available on humble bundle. This game shakes up combat by offering you an upgrade every so often, which will augment your current robot into something with better weapons, which is cool. Boss designs are pretty interesting, and the music is intense enough to help gameplay, and simple enough to not distract. Controls feel pretty good, and combat feels natural - well, natural if you're a supercharged robot vulkaiser. You could do a lot worse.

17307254.review:
While not a game-changer for the genre, Vulkaiser does enough things competently to be an appreciable scrolling shoot-'em-up. The first, definite eyecatcher is the delightful homage to mecha sentai anime of the 1970s that suffuses the whole thing, from the cheesy intro and theme song all the way down to little details like those yellow subtitles that should be familiar to anyone who's sat down to watch anime in the VHS days. This weakens a little in the actual game, which has some pleasantly goofy but otherwise very unimpressive spritework, including some enemies who emerge from the background, but barely signal their transition into the field of play by simply becoming lighter colored. The projectiles are the usual bullet-hell menagerie, without any particularly interesting patterns or designs. It's a definite low-res affair and not much to look at.

Gameplay uses the "charge while firing" mechanic seen in some games like Hellbound, where after firing for a while you fill up a meter (with accompanying audio cue) and can unleash a minor "super" attack. This is initially quite weak. However, the one small novelty is that, in lieu of powerups, you can choose to fuse with one of your four teammates, each giving you an additional secondary fire and upgrading your super attack to something more useful. Each one is meant to have its own situational niche and style, and they do a pretty good job of distinguishing them. As far as I can tell so far, you get your pick of any of the four to start with, but it seems like, thereafter, you can only choose to take or decline a single randomly chosen one at certain fixed points in the subsequent levels. It appears levels give you one pick at the beginning and another shortly before the boss. Functionally it's still a fixed-position powerup system, but it does at least add a little bit of choice in your playstyle and strategy.

All in all, though it's decent, I'm not strictly sure I could recommend this for shmup fans at large, but those with a fondness for chintzy, hot-blooded old mecha shows might find the style enough to propel this robot into their Steam libraries.

A stylish SHMUP that draws heavily from old mecha-anime. From the tight graphics and sprites, to the funk-pop soundtrack. -tight challenging gameplay

CONS
-retro experience may alienate some players

16282433.review:
Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser is a really fun game even though I'm not too big of side scrolling bullet genre. As a big mecha fan I really enjoyed the homages to the different super robots of the 70s with their bright colours and funny looking enemy designs. That being said the game itself is quite short but that doesn't stop it from being fun.

The game consists of four levels of difficulty and the option of playing the launch mode straight away or practice mode where you can access all six levels and get used to the level before trying it on the launch mode. An interesting feature with this game is that bullets are able to hit your hands and feet without you taking any damage, Vulkaiser's chest is your hitbox and as long as it doesn't hit an enemy blast you won't lose health.

You have the option to combine with four different types of support units or face the enemies alone with the base Vulkaiser and its rocket fists. Be careful though, if your support unit is destroyed during a stage it cannot be repaired. My personal favorite is the Lightning unit since it can clear mass swarms of enemies and is great for boss fights.

Some things that the game can add to make it better include:
-A pause button, something that can really help since you're forced to play the whole six levels in one go.
-An options menu, this is a big one since there's no guide to the control keys. Luckily I played the Satazius demo and learned the keys from that but if I went in blind, I'd be absolutely lost in terms of controls.
-Additional levels or the choice to choose levels after being defeated. Whilst the game is short it is a bit frustrating to hit the last boss and be forced back to the first level and go through everything again before getting back to the boss.


I'm a big mecha fan and if you enjoy side shooters and giant robots then this game is for you. It's short and sweet but something about it makes me want to keep shooting away at hordes of enemy robots and their retro design.

16263277.review:
A good chunk of my early play time with Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser was spent with a grin on my face. As someone who’s watched his fair share of old Japanese cartoons, it really is a well observed little thing. From the slightly cheap looking splash screens, the pompy music, even the loading screens and level title cards, it’s chock full of character. Then there’s the game itself, you’re a giant red robot who can fire his fists like missiles and combine with his co-pilots like Power Rangers. 

It’s not all just for colour either, which pilot you combine with affects your type of attack. Take Rocket Kaiser for example, combine with him and your shots will be accompanied by powerful missiles, with the charged weapon essentially being a huge bomb, great for taking down powerful enemies, but a spread of enemies could easily swarm you. In that case you’d be better off with Needle Kaiser, a wide shot type, but she’s weak both in terms of armour and damage dealt. Drill Kaiser is hugely powerful, but her range is tiny, meaning you’re putting yourself in danger every time you attack. Thunder Kaiser is something of a mix, his standard attack has decent range, his charge shot is powerful, but his bomb is feeble 

Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser has a peculiar kind of difficulty, the most notable thing is that it must be beaten on a single credit, there’s no continues to be had. Playing on the easy difficulty I’ve raced to the end of the game, once not even really trying whilst capturing our First Play video. The step up to the next difficulty level though made me hit a wall I’ve struggled to get past. I’m not sure what it is that’s stopping me from getting better at the game, it could just be that I’m not the gamer I used to be. I do sometimes feel a bit blind to the incoming bullets, but no more than any other shooter, but I think it’s actually more to do with the shame of Vulkaiser. Your hitpoint is fairly small, still easy to hit, but only a tiny part of your giant mech, but because you’re essentially controlling a giant line whilst looking at the enemy, it’s very easy to drag it in to incoming fire.

Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser is a little sparse in terms of modes. There’s the story mode and ‘training’, which is just the main missions there for you to retry. I’m not sure Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser is the game to spend hours practising, learning patterns. The training mode does allow you to complete stages though, opening up the next one you couldn’t reach in a single run. It’s not a bad way to see the later levels on the harder difficulties, which at least helps keep things interesting. If you are chasing score then it does separate them by difficulty, and I think the scoring system works by rewarding you for destroying enemies as quickly as possible as they appear on screen, so maybe there is something to be said for spending the time learning patterns. 

In terms of presentation, the game has no resolution options. As soon as you hit play though you’re presented with the option to go full screen, which may seem like a small thing, and does cause some problems on a 2 screen set up, as it merely changes your resolution to match the game’s. It’s welcome though, we’ve reviewed a couple of games in the past year or so that haven’t had that option. One of the drawbacks though, and this is kind of funny if you’re not playing seriously, is it means that when you unlock an achievement, or a friend signs in to Steam, you can’t see a third of the screen. So if you are planning a serious run at the game, maybe turn off notifications. 

There’s no doubting Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser is fun, but a lot of that comes from its charm. It does a great job of harking back to old-school anime, both in tone and theme. I’m less sure the game itself rates as highly or holds up to repeated playthroughs. Which is a shame, I really like the mecha gimmick of combining with the other pilots, and their strengths and weaknesses do add a level of strategy to the game, it’s just a shame the level design doesn’t build on it, instead feeling more like a shooting gallery. Still, for the price it’s a fun bit of nostalgia, hard to dislike, and not something you’ll have seen too often
